Title: Prove: $\int_0^1 \frac{\ln x }{x-1} d x=\sum_1^\infty \frac{1}{n^2}$
Content:
I'd like your help with proving that
$$\int_0^1 \frac{\ln x }{x-1}d x=\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^2}.$$
I tried to use Fourier series, or to use a power series and integrate it twice but it didn't work out for me. Any suggestions? Thanks!
AcceptedAnswer:
Hint: use the substitution $u=1-x$ to obtain
$$
I:=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln x}{x-1}dx=-\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\ln \left( 1-u\right) 
}{u}\,du
$$ and the following Maclaurin series $$
\ln \left( 1-u\right) =-u-\frac{1}{2}u^{2}-\frac{1}{3}u^{3}-\ldots -\frac{
u^{n+1}}{n+1}-\ldots\qquad(\left\vert u\right\vert <1) 
$$
